step_by_step_thinking: The patient developed flank pain, oliguria, hematuria, and elevated creatinine post-hysterectomy. During the procedure, vessel ligation occurred. The Artery of Sampson (a branch of the internal iliac artery) supplies the bladder and its ligation could cause bladder ischemia, leading to hematuria and flank pain. The superior vesical artery (C) is also part of the internal iliac artery and supplies the bladder, but the Artery of Sampson is specifically associated with bladder ischemia. Uterine artery (D) ligation is common but less directly linked to renal symptoms. Ovarian artery (B) ligation would affect the ovary, not the bladder or kidneys. The renal ultrasound being normal suggests no obstruction, aligning with bladder ischemia from Artery of Sampson ligation.
